claims.text: Scientists at UCT have uncovered garlic's cancer-fighting properties.
claims.context: Research by UCT lecturer Dr. Katherine Kushula on garlic's effects.

claims.text: Scientists at UCT have uncovered garlic's cancer-fighting properties.
claims.context: Research by UCT lecturer Dr. Katherine Kushula on garlic's effects.

claim_reports.claim_text: Scientists at UCT have uncovered garlic's cancer-fighting properties.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources indicate that garlic contains compounds with potential cancer-fighting properties, including studies discussing its medicinal effects and specific compounds like ajoene that disrupt cancer cell mechanisms. Additionally, a YouTube source confirms research from UCT supporting these findings.

supports.title: (PDF) The Immunomodulation and Anti-Inflammatory Effects of ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the potential of garlic (Allium sativum) in reducing cancer risk, highlighting its medicinal properties and active compounds that may combat various stages of cancer.
supports.snippet: Background Many authors have explored the intriguing possibility that the regular intake of Allium sativum (garlic) might reduce cancer risk.

supports.title: Garlic-derived anticancer agents: structure and biological activity of ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses garlic's medicinal properties and its activity against various stages of cancer, suggesting that it has cancer-fighting properties.
supports.snippet: Garlic has been used throughout the centuries to treat infections, heart disease, and cancer. Ajoene is one of the main compounds formed from heating crushed ...

supports.title: [PDF] The garlic compound ajoene covalently binds vimentin, disrupts the ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the cancer-fighting properties of ajoene, a compound derived from garlic, and its mechanisms of action in cancer cells, supporting the claim that garlic has cancer-fighting properties.
supports.snippet: In this study we identify vimentin as a target that undergoes thiolysis exchange with ajoene in cancer cells. We show that the covalent modification of vimentin ...

supports.title: Can Garlic prevent cancer? - YouTube
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that researchers at UCT have found that a compound in garlic can kill cancer cells, supporting the claim about garlic's cancer-fighting properties.
supports.snippet: ... UCT lecturer Dr. Catherine Kaschula and her team have established how a compound found in crushed cloves of garlic killed cancer cells ...

transcript_data.text: It's my feelgood breakfast show. A feel good breakfast show. This is Espresso. Thank you so much for joining us on our live show this morning. Now before the break, I said health properties and there might be something in it for all of us when we talk about garlic. Now aside from the fact that it tastes incredible. We all know that garlic has both culinary and medical benefits. But scientists at the UC tea uh they say that they've uncovered garlic's cancer fighting properties. So in this new research UCT lecturer Dr. Katherine Kushula and her team, they've established how a compound, a compound found in crushed garlic cloves can actually kill cancer cells. And with us in studio to talk about it is Dr. Kula herself. Dr. Welcome to the show. Hi, lovely to be here. I'm excited about this because we're saying cancer killing properties from a compound that's found in crushed garlic cloves. Now, I want to get down to this. Why it needs to be crushed? Does it need to be heated? How effective is it in killing cancer? I mean what what are we talking about here? Well, the thing is I suppose because we are scientists and we're coming from the chemistry department, we actually want to understand what the compounds are that are present in garlic that are having this effect. And in actual fact, when the clove is first crushed, there's a compound allisonin which is released which is more antibacterial properties. But this compound actually changes over time when the preparation is heated as in a food preparation into this cancer fighting compound called auine. And it's got dulfide bonds in it, which means it also has this potent garlic smell. And we've actually shown that auine is able to enter into the cancer cell and it's actually able to disrupt the intracellular machinery in the cancer cell and bring about a toxic effect and kill that cancer cell. I'm gobsmacked that we're going back to natural remedies. I mean, you guys are scientists. We expect you to work with chemicals and all kinds of crazy stuff, but here we're talking about stuff that's in our kitchen cupboards. Can this property or auine like you you mentioned can it fight any type of cancer or is it only effective in some? Well, it's been shown to be cytotoxic to a range of different types of cancers. Although I think what's more relevant to the human condition because it's a dietary compound and there's a lot of epidemiological um evidence to show that actually populations of people who consume high quantities of garlic have lower incidence of gastrointestinal cancer specifically of the stomach and colon. So um I would think that you know you would probably obtain the highest concentration of this compound through a meal which has been prepared with the akawine in it. In other words, being cooked and probably exposure to um you know, oral exposure to gastrointestinal cancers would probably have a greater effect. Although we have shown in the laboratory that it is also able um to act against other cancer cell types, but I think for the human condition, it's probably more gastrointestinal tract. It's exciting because now that means we can add more garlic to our food because you're saying that we need to do it while cooking. This is also the first time that you see this because like you said, scientists wants to see how the auin or how the garlic properties actually work. What's the best way to try and consume it? I mean, take us back there. Should it always be crushed or cooked? Yes. Well, if you want to get this cancer fighting chemical, and I say it's a chemical, it's a natural compound, but it is still a chemical, and it's present in your garlic. You actually need to take your crushed clove and actually you need to take your clove, crush it, and then in order to achieve um this transformation of what's in the crushed clove into what's what's going to be present in your food preparation, you actually need to heat the preparation and you actually get a chemical transformation which takes place between a compound which is produced in the crush clove and then it gets transformed through heating into this aching compound. So um the the preparation would involve cooking of the clove which I think is actually a process which we do do when we prepare. So possibly we knew about this in some way. I don't know in some way or another doctor it's exciting stuff and it's exciting that even scientists are coming back to our kitchen to show us how to prepare things and to make things better. So thank you so much for joining us on our show today. Well there you heard it an excuse to add more garlic to that pizza. It's really good news. So make sure you try some on your next dinner date especially if you know him for the first time. Okay, but there's loads more happening on our feelood breakfast show. In fact, even though it can leave a smile the next day, we all know that garlic is so good for us. And it looks like Andrea has more details on this.
